intro: Chamaesyce carunculata, commonly known as the redstem sandmat, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a low-growing annual or biennial herb that typically reaches heights of 10 to 30 centimeters. The plant features fleshy, ribbed stems that are often reddish in color, and its leaves are usually opposite, ovate, and covered with fine hairs. Its small, yellow flowers are clustered in dense inflorescences, and the plant is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. Chamaesyce carunculata is often found in sandy or gravelly soils, and it plays a role in stabilizing dunes and preventing erosion.
